<section data-auto-animate>
<h2>Traditional Formats</h2>
  <ul>
    <li>[Typst](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/typst.html), an open-source typesetting system (revised LaTeX).</li>
  </ul>
::: {.columns}
::: {.column}
<div style="font-size:0.6em; color:#005fae;">

```typst
= Introduction

This is a little paragraph, and it contains
some _italic_ as well as some *bold* text,
and here is some `monospace` stuff.

If you want to #underline[put a line] under
some text, you can use this implemented function.

The following command makes links underlined.

#show link: underline

This works: #link("https://typst.app/")[Here] is a link.

Lists
- just use the markdown syntax,
- and hence are very easy.

Numbered lists
+ also use this easy syntax,
+ so they are no more difficult.

Extended functionality is provided by the
`list` and `enum` functions.

Here is some $a = 2 b + 1$ inline math.
For centered equations, let's first enable numbering.

#set math.equation(numbering: "(1)")

Now here are some examples:
(note the space at the beginning and at the end)

$ "area" = A = pi r^2 = pi dot "radius"^2 $ <myequation>

$ cal(A) := { x in RR | x "is natural" } $

$ sum_(k=0)^n k
    &= 1 + ... + n \
    &= (n(n+1)) / 2 $

$ mat(
  1, 2, ..., 10;
  2, 2, ..., 10;
  dots.v, dots.v, dots.down, dots.v;
  10, 10, ..., 10;
) $

You perhaps noted that I labeled @myequation,
and now you saw how I can refer to it.
```

<section data-auto-animate>
<h2>[Publishing Platforms](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/)</h2>
<p><em>allow users to publish or host their html-generated content.</em></p>
<p> <strong>[GitHub](https://github.com/UCANR-IGIS/quarto-showcase)</strong> is a common platform for collaborative work and publishing lightweight pages</p>
  <ul>
    <li class="fragment"> Users create a ["repository" or repo](https://github.com/UCANR-IGIS/quarto-showcase)</li>
    <li class="fragment"> Users work locally in their projects (qmd or notebooks)</li>
    <li class="fragment"> Publish to the repo (including rendered html products)</li>
    <li class="fragment"> ... and connect them to [GitHub pages](https://ucanr-igis.github.io/quarto-showcase/) </li>
    <li class="fragment"> Alternatively: [GitHub Actions](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/github-pages.html)</li>
    <li class="fragment"> Example: [NASA Openscapes Page](https://nasa-openscapes.github.io/) and [repo](https://github.com/nasa-openscapes) 
  </ul>
  
</section>

<section data-auto-animate>
<h2>[Publishing Platforms](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/)</h2>
<p><em>allow users to publish or host their html-generated content.</em></p>
  <ul>
    <li class="fragment"> [Quarto Pub](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/quarto-pub.html) easily publishes small quarto projects as static websites visible to the public.</li>
    <li class="fragment"> [Posit Connect](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/rstudio-connect.html) allows you to publish data within an organization (free and paid options).</li>
    <li class="fragment"> [Netlify](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/netlify.html) is a professional platform for web publishing with more featuers (and a limited free plan).</li>
    <li class="fragment"> [AWS3](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/WebsiteHosting.html) offers static website hosting as well.</li><br>
  </ul>
<p class="fragment"> There are [MANY](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/) options for publishing, but GitHub tends to be favored by academics since it also offers version control and collaborative project management.</p>

</section>
